title: Tuesday, 5th January, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM

PM

PM

PM

PM

PM

I'll i have to share is an inflation chart that everyone else is sharing, so it must be interesting, right?

PM

Actually, it is a bit interesting

11:03 am
PM

PM

PM

That said, maybe lower energy prices are fueing what little recovery Europe has

11:04 am
BE

Well, thanks for that pep talk.

PM

PM

Will perk up

11:04 am
BE

Every day can't be like yesterday (which was of course the worst year opener session since the dot-comedy unwind.)

BE

Today, we pause.

BE

FTSE basically unchanged, give or take a point or two.

11:05 am
BE

With features rather than trends. Do you want to start with eco though?

PM

Sure

undefined
11:06 am
BE

So Eurozone HICP inflation unchanged at 0.2% y/y in December

BE

Consensus was 0.3%

BE

There's no component breakdown, which limits what we can say about it.

11:07 am
BE

BNP can say a bit, though.

BE

[The] main categories showed a moderation in annual food, alcohol and tobacco-price inflation, to 1.2% from 1.5% in November. Judged by the German and Italian preliminary data, this seems to be a broad-based outcome in the individual eurozone economies.

This moderation was offset by a slower pace of decline in energy price inflation. Annual energy HICP inflation posted a 5.9% fall, compared to a 7.3% fall in November. This is driven by energy-related base effects. But, note that the recent decline in oil prices continues to soften the strong energy-related base effects we expected initially.

Within core inflation, services inflation moderated by 0.1pp to 1.1%, back to its level in June. This is mainly driven by weaker-than-expected service-price inflation in Italy, which moderated by 0.3pp to 0.3% y/y in December. In the period ahead, the still high level of slack in the labour market and lower cost of production for corporates amid lower commodity prices – which should limit the potential for higher wage demands – suggest services inflation is likely to remain relatively subdued for a prolonged period.

Core goods inflation, meanwhile, was unchanged at 0.5% y/y. Effective exchange-rate depreciation has been filtering into core goods price inflation over the course of 2015 (core goods price inflation rose from -0.1% y/y in February to 0.6% y/y in October). But, the last two months has shown some signs of moderation in this component. The earlier seasonal discounting in some core components such as clothing and footwear suggests the corporates are trying to attract customers amid still weak domestic demand. This would, in turn, signal that the impact of a weaker EUR is in part absorbed by their profit margins. Over the coming year, however, we believe an improvement in domestic demand and the likely effect of the ECB’s quantitative easing on expectations and the effective exchange-rate has the potential to exert some upward pressure on core goods inflation.

In January, we expect eurozone HICP inflation to tick slightly higher to around 0.5% due to energy-related base effects. Note that the continuation in the decline in oil prices suggests the energy-related base effects will be less prominent than we expected initially. According to our estimates, headline inflation should moderate back to around 0.2% as early as February in the absence of a significant increase in euro-denominated oil prices.

BE

We can also do UK construction PMI, which was ahead, but I doubt interest will be overwhelming.

11:08 am
BE

So perhaps we should get onto retailers.

undefined
PM

Next?

Next PLC (NXT:LSE): Last: 6,765, down 425 (-5.91%), High: 7,000, Low: 6,755, Volume: 1.10m

Ah, right

(daughers)

11:10 am
BE

As we've said very often: crowded market, no differentiation .......

BE

... it was never entirely clear (at least to me) what Next's special sauce was, beyond doing delivery quite well.

BE

Though effectively selling Phillipines-stitched court suits and quite expensive furniture on hire-purchase APRs is quite profitable generally.

11:13 am
BE

Anyway, the bigger surprise is that Next got its stock levels wrong going into Christmas.

BE

Forecasts nudge down as a result, only by 1-2% ......

PM

Market reaction seems a tad harsh

11:13 am
BE

Well .... it's a stock priced for upgrades and for cash returns, and you're getting neither today.

BE

Here's Deutsche Bank.

BE

Next’s Christmas trading update disappointed our expectations on sales, with Directory (online) missing the most. Full year Jan-16 profit expectations have been broadly held but initial FY Jan-17 plans lie 4% below consensus at the midpoint. The buyback limit remains at 6962p and this is likely to rise to 7100p at the March prelims. The greater than 5.5% dividend yield remains a support but we see better value elsewhere. We trim forecasts 1-2% and retain our Hold rating.

11:14 am
BE

Next’s online division materially missed our expectations and consensus (per Bloomberg News also +8.4%) due to: 1) warm weather; 2) increased online completion as rivals’ service levels catch up and; 3) poor availability of best sellers as more was allocated to Retail (stores). Arguably at a Brand level the latter point should not be a major factor though. Competitor discounting versus Next’s full-price stance also played a part. At this stage the management-forecast £214m yoy increase in the credit book does not suggest consumer credit appetites are a constraint. However, as explored in our sector outlook (What’s in Store for 2016, 4 January) this could become an issue from April as the effect of cutting monthly minimum repayments from 9% to 5% annualises and UK base rates potentially rise.

BE

In FY Jan-17 management expects 1-6% sales and profit growth. From the midpoint of latest Jan-16 guidance (£817m) this implies PBT of £846m versus our prior £869m and Reuters consensus £879m. We believe the shape of the year ahead would consist of slower Directory growth (signs of The Label and International also slowing), similar space growth (net 300k sqft), flat gross margins and opex/ sales. Today the buyback limit stays at 6962p since management is using the bottom end of its range. However, at the 24 March Prelims we would expect this to increase to 7100p using the midpoint (and consistent 8% ERR methodology).

BE

We trim our full Q4 sales expectations, lowering FY Jan-16 PBT to £816m from £820m. We also lower FY Jan-17 Directory growth from 9% to 6% and thus total Brand to +3.9% (LFL +2.2%) and our PBT 1.4% to £856m (each 1% off Directory = c0.6% off PBT/ EPS but arguably also likely PE de-rating). As we write the shares are slightly below the current buyback limit but for now we maintain forecasts of special dividends at 65p/ quarter, up from 60p this year. At our unchanged DCF-based target of 7200p this implies a total dividend yield of 5.8%. We use unchanged assumptions of 8.4% WACC (4.5% ERP & RFR, 0.9 beta, 5.5% CoD), 1.5% nTGR and 19.5% terminal EBIT margin (Jan-16e 20.2%). Risks include: pace of Directory growth versus expectations; UK clothing market share gains/ (losses) particularly versus rival chain M&S.

11:15 am
BE

Canaccord ........

BE

Next's trading update is in the round disappointing, notwithstanding the central profit
guidance of £817m (+/-£7m) being within the range guidance of £810m - £845m.
This was understandably driven by the unseasonably warmer weather in November
and December, neatly shown by the graph in the RNS statement, but not helped by
a self-inflicted wound of poor stock availability within Directory. Management has
identified and recognised this internal weakness, which is being addressed, although full
resolution benefits are not expected to come through until Autumn/Winter 2016.
Next has delivered total Brand full price sales growth of 0.4% for the two-month period
up to Christmas Eve, compared with market consensus of a 5.8% increase (CGe:
+6.0%) . This splits (0.5%) for Retail (vs consensus of +3.2%) and 2.0% for Directory (vs
consensus of +10%). Total year-to-date Brand Full Price sales are up 3.7%, below the
bottom of range guidance of 4% – 6%, with Retail up 2.1% and Directory up 6.1%. Stock
into Sale is 7% down yoy, as Next bought more tightly this year - rightly as it transpires
given the unforeseen milder weather - given last year's surplus stock into Sale being
higher than wished. With gross margins maintained, Next is now guiding to full-year PBT
to be £817, compared with last guidance given at Q3 of £810m - £845m. (The 53rd
week is expected to add c £15m to PBT).
Next has also, as is its tradition, given its first quantified call on prospects for FY17.
It expects full price sales to grow by between 1% and 6%, with profits growing in line.
This implies FY17 PBT of between £825m and £866m against the central FY126 PBT
guidance of £817m. The buy back share price limit, based on its 8% ERR methodology,
has been maintained at £69.62. This implies the continuation of special dividends being
used to return surplus cash to shareholders, but will be reviewed at the March prelims.
Full-year net debt guidance is £670m.

BE

Impact on our view
Next remains a quality act, in our view, as shown by its ability to deliver PBT within its
guidance range, despite a shortfall against its full price sales guidance and the issue
of poor Directory stock availability. However, in light of the 3% shortfall to our FY16 PBT
forecast and its FY17 guidance, we are placing our recommendation, target price and
forecasts under review (prev. BUY, 8,800p target). We continue to believe that Next's
financial and retail disciplines are exemplary within the sector.
Valuation
On last night's close (and forecasts) the shares are trading a cal 16 PER of 15.2x falling
to 14.2x for cal 17, with corresponding EV/EBITDA of 10.5x and 10.0x, with an underlying
cal 16 dividend yield of 2.3% and a total yield, including special dividends, of 5.7%. The
shares have been drifting since early December as fears for clothing retailers increased
with the extended period of mild and unhelpful weather.

11:15 am
BE

And Jefferies.

BE

Next's Christmas trading has disappointed the market in part due to the warm
weather but also due to poor stock availability and increasing competition
online. What's more, the FY17e outlook guidance for 1%-6% sales and EBIT
growth is more cautious than the market expected. Having already cut our
forecasts, Next trades on c.15x our cal 17 EPS for c.10% TSR, which is not cheap
enough to attract us.
A poor sales performance, not just due to warm weather. Next has kicked off the
Christmas reporting season by missing expectations with full price sales growth of +0.4%,
short of our lowered 4% assumption and consensus of 5.7%. Within this full price directory
sales grew just 2%, below JEFe +7% and consensus of 8.4%. Given assumed growth of
c.20-25% in international online sales and the "Label" sales (together c.25% of Directory
sales), we estimate Next branded UK online sales fell c.6%. Management attributes this to; 1) the unseasonally warm weather through November and December, 2) poor stock availability going into the period, and 3) a better online offer from competitors as they catch up with Next's delivery offer. While Next should benefit next year from the two year warm weather comp, and stock availability can be addressed, we believe the better online competition
will be an ongoing pressure (as seen in our surveys and online comparison studies, see
"And the survey says"). Elsewhere, full price retail sales grew 0.4% (cons +3.2%/JEFe +2%) implying LFL retail sales fell c.3% (cons +0.4%, JEFe -0.6%), a marked change from +2.4% in the preceding quarter, against an easier comp.

BE

FY16e PBT range narrowed to £810m-£824m. Because Next is disciplined against
discounting, gross margins have been maintained as expected and thus the profit impact of
the lower sales has been well managed. The 52 week FY16e PBT range has been narrowed
from £810m-£845m to £810m-£824m suggesting consensus of £828m needs to fall by
1%-2%, however we had already cut to £810m.
A more cautious outlook for FY17e with full price sales and profit growth of
1%-6%. Perhaps more importantly, while Next has given its standard 5% range for the
following year's sales growth, the 1%-6% range is lower than the 2%-7% we expected.
With operating margins already c.20% there is no margin expansion upside and so 1%-6%
profit growth is significantly below Next's historic run rate (14.3% average PBT growth FY07-
FY15). We were already forecasting only 3.8% PBT growth to £841m in FY17e but consensus
expectations for 5.4% to £881m may prove toppy. Next's 1H17e may prove particularly
difficult given the tough gross margin comp (+100bps in Retail on exceptional buying).

11:16 am
BE

Cashflow and dividend solid but no increase in £69.62 buy-back limit. With
£377m of cashflow pre special dividends and funding for exceptional Directory debt, net
debt is expected to come in at £670m (JEFe £683m), however for the first time, Next has
not increased its share buy-back limit, based on the lower end of the profit guidance for
FY17e. The stock is trading on c.15x our cal 17 EPS but despite the PER contraction we see
little to attract at this stage given the diminishing multi-channel advantage and our forecast
for only 4% 3yr EPS CAGR.

BE

Sorry for all the grey, but we talk about Next so often I've slightly run out of my own opinions.

Home Retail Group PLC (HOME:LSE): Last: 106.67, up 7.97 (+8.08%), High: 106.80, Low: 99.65, Volume: 2.93m

11:19 am
BE

Haven't heard anything new on the Homebase sale rumours, though clearly that's a live story.

BE

There's a decent note out from Deutsche talking about the breakup value.

BE

We
assume that a potential bidder would pay a value for each division based on
achieving 3% EBIT margins (versus 2% today) achievable in Feb-18. We find it
hard to imagine any parties interested in acquisition if they were not also
confident of being able to achieve this level of profitability. We assume that around 40% of central costs could be saved, but that there would be dis-synergies of £40m equating to the gains targeted when the two businesses came together in 2002. We also include an estimate of the potential pension deficit and the Payment Protection Insurance provision run-off.
The implied multiples, based on our Feb-17 divisional forecasts, are around 14-16x. The problem for a potential break-up, however, would be that the dis-synergies which we think might be incurred would greater than the profits that might be generated by Homebase. Hence we find it difficult to envisage Homebase being disposed of by management, especially with the Argos concessions within Homebase proving successful. As a combined entity we think the group is less attractive to potential buyers: hence our base case is for no change in ownership, even if it could unlock value.

11:21 am
BE

BE

But to reiterate, we've not heard anything new on the idea of PE sniffing around, or Homebase being split off, or whatever. If we do before the end of the session, we'll come back to it.

Aberdeen Asset Management PLC (ADN:LSE): Last: 269.10, down 12.9 (-4.57%), High: 276.40, Low: 264.50, Volume: 3.88m
BE

Which is at a one-year low, at least.

11:25 am
BE

The note's slightly state-the-obvious, one could argue, though is interesting on the theme of Gilbert not doing enough belt tightening.

BE

More than just an EM play – Downgrading to UW: The Aberdeen share strongly
underperformed in 2015, down 33% vs the avg UK Asset Manager in our coverage
universe +16%. It is tempting to view the share as solely a macro call on EM sentiment.
However, we highlight that significant other areas remain vulnerable to outflow risk.
This would include the underperforming Global Equities desk, HY in Fixed Income, the
SWIP life book and the Multi-Asset area of Aberdeen Solutions. We forecast a slowing
of group outflows to £20bn in FY16 (from £34bn in FY15) but believe that risks are to
the downside. With a significantly lower asset base in 2016 yoy, revenue declines of -
13% yoy are projected. Cost rationalization plans appear modest in response. The share
is trading at 12.6x calendar 2016 PE for a projected 25% decline in EPS yoy. In the light
of this negative earnings momentum and outflow risk, we downgrade the stock to
Underweight, new target price 250p from 350p. The reduction in PT reflects lower EPS
estimates and a lower chosen 2016 PE multiple of 11x (from 11.5x previously).

PM

August 2012

11:26 am
BE

???

PM

Last time the stock was this low

BE

Ah.

11:26 am
PM

Sorry, i interrupted

BE

Just thinking ... Pity Aberdeen's not for sale at these discount prices. Which it clearly isn't.

BE

Given recent vociferous denials.

11:27 am
BE

Back to Barclays.

BE

2/3 of stock of AUM in areas of outflow risk: Aberdeen’s flow outlook is not just at
risk from macro EM sentiment, in our opinion. We highlight in 2015 there have been
significant outflows from Global Equities (£6bn) and the Multi-Asset area of Aberdeen
Solutions (£7bn). In total we identify ~£191bn or 2/3 of Aberdeen’s stock of AUM as
concentrated in areas of significant outflows in 2015, and sentiment into 2016 still
appears negative. This suggests outflow risk is firmly to the downside.

BE

Limited cost cutting response: Management identified £50m of potential cost saves to
offset the downwards pressure on management fees from lower average AUM base.
However, precise details on these savings were lacking and management asserted they
would be heavily back-loaded into 2017. This suggests operating margins are likely to
significantly decline in 2016 - we project down to 37% (from 42% in FY15).
8% downgrade to 2016E EPS: Our forecast changes cause an 8% cut to 2016E EPS to
22.5p and 6% to 2017E to 24.2p. We are now forecasting a 25% decline in EPS yoy in
FY16, then a 7% recovery in 2017. The share is trading at 12.6x calendar 2016E PE or
6.7% yield, although DPS cover looks thin for FY16. Our preference amongst the Asset
Management names is our top sector pick Henderson (OW, PT320p).

11:28 am
BE

In a quiet afternoon, we should perhaps revisit the Scottish Widows deal.

BE

An argument at the time was that Aberdeen wasn't diversifying, it was just diluting its client base with a load of accounts that could walk within six months and had no reason to do otherwise.

PM

PM

BE

Tesco PLC (TSCO:LSE): Last: 144.85, up 2.6 (+1.83%), High: 150.00, Low: 143.75, Volume: 13.63m
11:51 am
BE

Detusche -- again -- pushing as part of its Christmas update preview.

BE

Crap but cheap. That's the gist of it.

BE

We lower our
Tesco EPS estimates by c.10% and PT by 5% and make no changes to our
Sainsbury’s and Morrisons EPS estimates and PTs. However, sector share
prices have declined greater than 10% in the past 2 months, underperforming a broadly
flat market. TSCO is down 20%, SBRY is down 7% and MRW is down 16%
over that period. Given the 41% upside to our TSCO PT of 200p, and the 6%
upside to our MRW PT of 155p, we upgrade TSCO from Hold to Buy and MRW
from Sell to Hold. We believe Tesco's UK margin progression can outpace
rivals despite lacklusture LFL and forecast a 2.2% UK EBIT margin by 18/19.

11:51 am
BE

Morrisons, Sainsbury’s and Tesco will report Christmas trading on 12, 13 and 14 January respectively. Kantar data for Nov suggested a grocery market sales decline of -0.4%, and no easing of deflation. Specifically, Tesco’s relative performance was disappointing (please see our note “Another month of negative market growth” from 15 Dec). We believe expectations factor in potential volatility in sales performance and we do not expect these numbers to drive 15/16 profit warnings. Our 16/17E EPS are already 17% and 7% below consensus for Sainsbury’s and Morrisons respectively and 2% above at Tesco.

BE

We lower our Tesco UK Q3 and Q4 LFL forecasts from +0.1% to -2.5% and from -2.3% to -3.4% respectively. The strong valuation support we refer to relies on meaningful UK EBIT margin progression, from +0.5% in H1 15/16 to a normalized 2.2% by 18/19. We expect commercial gross margin gains and cost cutting to play a major role in our margin improvement forecast and we expect to see evidence of this in the H2 EBIT margin (DBe +1.4%), which would show 90bps margin progress despite the negative LFL (DBe -2.9%).

BE

We forecast a -0.8% LFL for Sainsbury’s in FY Q3 (cal Q4). We forecast a -1.5% LFL for Morrisons for the 9 weeks to Christmas, within a -2.0% FY Q4 LFL. At Sainsbury’s, we recognize some risk on the non-food side. Clothing, which we estimate represents 3% to 4% of sales ex fuel, had been growing at c.10% and is margin accretive. Unseasonable warm weather could negatively impact clothing profits but ultimately, it’s still a minor part of the business and we’d expect the impact to be negligible (please see our note “Roadshow Take-Aways” from 8 Dec). We expect flooding to have a negligible impact across the board, even at Morrisons where we expect increased trade at unaffected stores to largely offset lost sales, although this could impact cost efficiency.

11:52 am
BE

Our Tesco, Sainsbury’s and Morrisons PTs are DCF based, using a terminal growth rate of 0% and a WACC of 6.0% for SBRY and MRW and 6.5% for TSCO. We rate Tesco Buy (PT 200p), using a normalised 2.2% EBIT UK EBIT margin (2.9% group EBIT margin), 2.6% capex/sales. We rate Sainsbury Hold (PT 265p), using a normalised 2.2% EBIT margin, 2.8% capex/sales. We rate Morrison Hold (PT 155p), using a normalised 2.6% EBIT margin, 2.5% capex/sales. Downside risks for Tesco include a failure to improve profits via. commercial gross margin.

Patisserie Holdings PLC (CAKE:LSE): Last: 413.00, down 2 (-0.48%), High: 414.00, Low: 410.00, Volume: 290.21k
PM

11:57 am
BE

Yeah, they trashed the legacy of the one in Soho to roll out their corporate cakery thing, which is basically like British Rail catering with a tricolore stuck on it.

BE

Anyway, Peel Hunt downgrade.

BE

The shares have put in a stellar performance (+20%) since the
full year results in November. At the time we moved to Add from
Hold but the share price has now overshot our target price by
some distance. We remain positive on management and the longterm
prospects for the business. However, at 31x September
2016 earnings the short to medium-term multiple looks a little
full. Therefore, we move back to a Hold and wouldn’t
discourage some top slicing at this level.

11:57 am
BE

A growing appreciation: In its relatively short life as a quoted company,
Patisserie Holdings has managed to under promise and over deliver –
something management deserve credit for. This, and a growing
appreciation/awareness of the business, has helped to drive a significant
rerating of the shares. However, the recent strong share price performance
leaves the shares looking a little over valued in the short-term.
Valuation: A prospective PE of c31x to September 2016, falling to 27x in
2017, looks full for a business forecast to achieve 19% and 13% EPS growth
respectively. Whilst Patisserie has a track record of over delivery, it is not by
such magnitude that our numbers are likely to be materially beaten.
Long-term positive: It is possible that management may well use the
multiple and strong balance sheet (net cash £14m FY16E) to acquire and
further boost earnings. In addition, we remain confident in our forecasts and
expect management to be able to deliver in FY16. Our base case model
assumes 2% LFL growth and a disciplined rollout of c20 Patisserie Valerie
stores per annum achieving c20% growth in the current financial year. We
continue to be positive on the business over the long-term and merely see the
shares pausing for breath after such a strong run.

BE

I believe this is the reason: http://europa.eu/r...ase_IP-16-2_en.htm

BE

The European Commission has opened an in-depth investigation to assess whether the United Kingdom's plans to support the conversion of part of the Drax coal power plant to operate on biomass are in line with EU state aid rules.

The Commission fully supports Member State efforts to increase the use of renewable energy and pursue EU energy and climate objectives. At the same time, EU state aid rules make sure that the cost of such support for consumers is limited and does not give certain operators an unfair advantage over competitors. Therefore, the Commission will now investigate further to make sure that the public funds used to support the Drax project are limited to what is necessary and do not result in overcompensation. It will also assess whether the positive effects of the project in achieving EU energy and environmental objectives outweigh potential competition distortions in the market for biomass. The opening of an in-depth investigation gives the UK and interested third parties an opportunity to submit comments. It does not prejudge the outcome of the investigation.
